event.doc_name: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs Leobardo Moreno Galvez, Jose Luis Vicente Ramos, and Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera are immigrant youth under the age of 21 who have applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS), a form of humanitarian relief that provides vulnerable youth with a path to long‑term legal status.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs are immigrant youth under 21 who have applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS), a form of humanitarian relief that provides vulnerable youth with a path to long‑term legal status.

evidence.text: In each Plaintiff’s case, a Washington state court has made these requisite findings, and each Plaintiff has thus applied for SIJS.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Each plaintiff has a state‑court order that qualifies as an SIJS order.

evidence.text: Leobardo submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS on December 2, 2016. On December 20, 2018, USCIS denied his application solely based on its erroneous policy requiring predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: In October 2016, the Skagit County Superior Court placed him in the custody of a state agency or department and entered a SIJS order.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Leobardo Moreno Galvez (20‑year‑old citizen of Mexico) was placed in custody by Skagit County Superior Court in October 2016, received an SIJS order, filed his petition with USCIS on December 2, 2016, and was denied by USCIS on December 20, 2018.

evidence.text: In June 2018, the Pierce County Superior Court appointed Jose’s relative as his guardian in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding, during which the court also entered an SIJS order. On February 5, 2019, USCIS denied his application solely based on its erroneous policy…
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Jose Luis Vicente Ramos (20‑year‑old citizen of Guatemala) was appointed a guardian by Pierce County Superior Court in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding in June 2018, received an SIJS order, filed his petition with USCIS on February 5, 2019, and was denied by USCIS on that same date.

evidence.text: In November 2017, the Pierce County Superior Court appointed Angel’s relative as a guardian in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding, during which the court also entered an SIJS order. On November 15, 2017, Angel submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS. USCIS has not adjudicated his SIJS petition.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera (19‑year‑old citizen of Mexico) was appointed a guardian by Pierce County Superior Court in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding in November 2017, received an SIJS order, filed his petition with USCIS on November 15, 2017, and USCIS has not adjudicated the petition.

evidence.text: Two have been unlawfully denied SIJS and the other faces imminent denial. Scores of other youth in Washington State face the same threat.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Two plaintiffs have been unlawfully denied SIJS and the third faces imminent denial; scores of other youth in Washington State face the same threat.

evidence.text: In February 2018, USCIS’s legal counsel purportedly issued “new guidance” for USCIS, which was never published on its website… the guidance states that the SIJS statute requires a state court have the authority to return a child to the custody of his or her parent in order for that court to find reunification is not viable…
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) policy began in February 2018, implementing a new guidance that requires state courts to have authority to reunify petitioners with their parents to issue an SIJS order, a requirement not supported by statute or regulation.

evidence.text: Since 2017, USCIS has routinely and as a matter of practice delayed the adjudication of SIJS petitions for months beyond this statutory deadline. ... In February 2018, USCIS began to issue Notices of Intent to Deny (NOIDs) and denials to applicants in Texas, New York, California, and now Washington, implementing its novel position…
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS has been delaying adjudication of SIJS petitions beyond the statutory 180‑day deadline, issuing Notices of Intent to Deny (NOIDs) and denials to plaintiffs in Washington State.

evidence.text: USCIS contends that Washington state courts lack the authority to issue SIJS findings to 18‑to‑20‑year‑olds because Washington courts do not have authority to order the physical reunification of those youth with their parents…
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: The SIJS statute contains no such requirement, providing only that the state court must determine that “reunification with one or both of the immigrant’s parents is not viable…”.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS denies SIJS petitions for youth 18‑20 because it claims state courts lack authority to reunify petitioners with their parents, a position inconsistent with the INA and the TVPRA.

evidence.text: The named plaintiffs are typical of the class because plaintiffs’ claims arise from the same alleged policy and course of conduct and are based on the same facts and the same legal theories…
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The plaintiffs’ claims arise from the same alleged policy and course of conduct and are based on the same facts and legal theories, making them typical class members.

evidence.text: The plaintiffs bring this class action to challenge the federal government’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJS petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin the government’s policy of refusing to adjudicate SIJS petitions in accordance with the INA and the APA.

Order Granting Plaintiffs’ Motion for Summary Judgment and Permanent Injunction
Order Granting Plaintiffs’ Motion for Class Certification
Order Regarding Defendants’ Motion for Reconsideration

args.reason: All checklist items have been fully extracted with complete evidence and no Not Applicable entries remain.
All distinct facts of the case have been extracted from the available documents, and no further actionable items remain.
